Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Exploring the Chemistry of Energy Applications, Living Systems, and Supramolecular Assemblies (ExCELS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) at the National Science Foundation supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site led by Professor Surita R. Bhatia at the State University of New York at Stony Brook (SBU). This REU site will host an REU Summer Program entitled Exploring the Chemistry of Energy Applications, Living Systems, and Supramolecular Assemblies (ExCELS). The ExCELS program is centered on three technical areas of strength at SBU; Energy, Living Systems, and Supramolecular Assemblies; while still being broad enough to attract students with diverse interests. Students will be trained in skills relevant to their research projects which may include organic synthesis, polymer synthesis, solid state synthesis, cell culture and sterile techniques, high resolution NMR, mass spectrometry, fluorescence microscopy, CD, and Raman spectroscopy. The program targets participation of female, minority, and deaf and hard-of-hearing students, including students from community colleges and non-PhD granting institutions where research opportunities are limited. Thus, it will broaden the diversity of the workforce in chemistry.

The REU is based on the three research strengths at SBU so that students are exposed to a coherent intellectual theme within a cluster. Specific objectives of the ExCELS REU are to: (1) Encourage and motivate students to pursue graduate studies in chemistry, with a focus on recruitment of underrepresented populations, including deaf and hard-of-hearing students; (2) Train students to transition from dependent to independent researchers through a focus on mentoring and research seminars by faculty and graduate students; (3) Enable students to communicate science effectively through active participation in "cluster" meetings involving students and faculty from multiple research groups; and (4) Provide students with strategies for professional success through a Professional Development Seminar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stony Brook University (SBU) hosted the REU Summer Site entitled Exploring the Chemistry of Energy Applications, Living Systems, and Supramolecular Assemblies (ExCELS) for three summers. The ExCELS program brings students from across the country to Stony Brook University for the summer to participate in cutting-adge research in chemistry.

The ExCELS program was centered around three technical areas of strength at Stony Brook University: applications of chemistry to energy technologies, drug design and biomedical devices, and self-assembling materials. Students were exposed to current research within each area, but the program itself was broad enough to appeal to students with diverse interests. Students were trained in a broad range of skills relevant to their research projects, which might include organic synthesis, polymer synthesis, solid state synthesis, cell culture and sterile technique, high resolution NMR, mass spectrometry, fluorescence microscopy, CD, and Raman spectroscopy.  The program targeted participation of female, minority, and deaf and hard-of-hearing students, including students from community colleges and non-PhD granting institutions where research opportunities are limited, thus broadening the diversity of the workforce in chemistry. 

In total, 25 students were trained during the grant period. Participants to date have included 13 women (52%), 13 underrepresented minorities (52%) and three disabled students (12%). Home institutions of the students included Drew University, Elmira College, Savannah State University, SUNY Albany, Prairie State College, University of Massachusetts Amherst, Wright State University, SUNY Potsdam, SUNY Oneonta, Fordham University, Swarthmore College, University of Puerto Rico Rio Piedras, Universidad Metropolitana, University of Rhode Island, Muhlenberg College, St. John’s University, Elizabeth City State University, and the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (NTID) at Rochester Institute of Technology. The program has supported participants who are first-generation college students, students from minority-serving institutions, and students from small colleges where research options are limited. Thus, it has provided training and experience to encourage these students to continue on and pursue advanced degrees and research careers in chemistry and other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields.
